Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: This is a very well done and enjoyable movie. The thing is, you have to understand the 50's and the Cold war to understand the movie. Many of us who grew up in the 50's lived through the Cold War and the threat of nuclear disaster. This movie reflects the fears of that era. The Korean War was fresh in many people's minds, the treatment of the POW's by the North Koreans opened many people's eyes to just how insidious and ruthless the Communists were. Samuel Fuller fought with the Big Red One in WWII and he saw the ruthlessness of another ideology when they liberated a concentration camp. Put this all together and you have the basis for this movie. Love it or hate it but this movie reflects the Cold War mentality, as does Night People.
Title: Hell and High Water

Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: This is a Cold War era about what would happen if the Koreans (this is set during the Korean War, which ended during the year of its release) got a hold of an A-bomb and dropped it in a way to frame the United States.  Richard Widmark plays Capt. Adam Jones who is hired for a mysterious mission to trail a freighter in an old Japanese submarine.  He hires some of his old Navy crew and takes the famed atomic scientist Prof. Montel (Victor Francen) and his assistant Prof. Denice Gerard (Bella Darvi) on board as the directors of their mission.They run afoul of Korean defenses including a very good sub battle, an island raid, and the final conflict I will leave to you to experience.  Widmark carries most of the dramatic load, the crew provides a bit of pathos and some enjoyable comic relief.  Victor Francen is believable as the bearded scientist and Bella Darvi looks pretty enough on screen (but not a real actress).The special effects were very good for their time, but the Cinemascope cannot be appreciated on your TV no matter how high the quality or its dimensions.  However, it is an enjoyable tale and can be enjoyed by the family.Reviewed by Craig Matteson, Ann Arbor, MI
summary: A cold war submarine tale from the end of the Korean War
Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: **** 1954. Written and directed by Samuel Fuller. One nomination for the Academy awards (Best Special Effects). Capt. Adam Jones, accompanied by two scientists, must find an island in the North Pacific ocean where Chinese are believed to build an atomic bomb. I love the extravaganza of the cinema of Samuel Fuller, Who else could have imagined a love scene between Richard Widmark and Bella Darvi in a submarine resting on the bottom of the ocean ? In a red light in order to conserve electricity and unable to speak because of the lack of oxygen ? This is cinema at its best. Highly recommended.
Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: Set at the height of the Cold War, this Sam Fuller thriller has Richard Widmark as a former navy sub commander recruited by a private group to stop Red China from getting the bomb.  Action packed with a cast that includes Cameron Mitchell, a lot of fun.  Sure it's dated. Love it anyway.
Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: Another good Navy story.  Richard Widmark was very convincing as the captain and the plot was very right for the time.  Some of the effects of the explosion did not seem as accurate as we now might know but a good story just the same.

Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: HELL AND HIGH WATER(1954) Directed and Written by Samuel Fuller. Scipt by Jesse Kasky Jr. Make up by Ben Nye. Score by Alfred Newman. Special effects by Ray Kellogg.Starring Richard Widmark, Bella Darvi, Cameron Mitchell, Richard Loo, Henry Kulky, Gene Evans, David Wayne and Victor Francen.A private group of scientists hire a crew former American navy men to pilot a surplus Japanese submarine to investigate North Atlantic islands believed to have a Red--aka Red Chinese--atomic base. In spite of a variety of troubles from Red opposition to having a woman onboard, the crew discover that there is indeed a Red Atomic base, they have an American B-52, an nuclear bomb and a monstrous plan to discredit the United States. Can --and should--the crew do anything to stop them.......or should they just report it to the appropriate authorities??Though Sam Fuller has the reputation of being some cinematic genius, I have never thought so finding his film interesting and watchable but almost always lumpy, underdone and not as good as they would be if a less exalted director had handled the material. And it is pretty much the same here.There is a great concept here, more than one excellent sequence and/or moments, the score is superb and the special effects consistently effective and more than a little jawdropping(see the oil dump battle sequence). The film has the feel of the Men's adventure magazines of that period. The battle sequences are all good. Unfortunately as this is Fuller, we have to take our lumps and our underdone potatoes. The script is too talky by ten minutes and should have been trimmed. Much of this tallkiness is taken up with the always trying "broad on a sub plot" which is worse here considering what is at state. While I know Darryl Zanuck was stumpfing Darvi and Fuller was stuck with her, there comes a time in every action/adventure film where you stick da broad in the background and let the men take over. Fuller never does constantly allowing the Darvi plot to intrude upon the main plot thus never letting it build up steam. Fuller's dialogue was never his strong point in any case and his idea of humor is turgid. The film needed to be a tight 80/90 minutes instead it lumbers far too long at 103.As such, the actors never quite get to come alive. Mitchell's character is impossible and he can do nothing with it. Evans and Wayne might just as well not be in the picture being gloried extras. As an actress, Darvi made for excellent w ore for Zanuck. Widmark is okay in an underwritten part as is Francen.The film is not bad and has much to recommend but oh for a Don Siegal of an F. Lee Thompson................Incidentally the Chinese did not have the A Bomb in 1954 so one must assume that this was actually a Soviet operation using the Chinese as their operatives...........The film IS also of interest since the basic plot is not all that different from some of the later Bond films--particularly OCTOPUSSY.....and is probably the first time it was used.....Oh and while the DVD print is gorgeous, it is the prime example of how letterboxing can kill a film. It is like looking through a mail slot!!!
summary: Okay we have a problem. The Red Chinese have an A Bomb and there is a broad on the Submarine!!
Title: Hell and High Water

reviewText: And bit of melodrama, some good submarine scenes. A good movie. We don't always get a chance to watch these.
